title: 114_s2134
content: The Act titled "Grow Our Own Directive: Physician Assistant Employment and Education Act of 2015" establishes a pilot program to provide educational assistance to physician assistants employed at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Grow Our Own Directive" pilot program provides educational assistance to former members of the Armed Forces for training as physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience. The pilot program provides educational assistance to former Armed Forces members with medical or military health experience to train as physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have a degree in a health-related science field and experience in delivering health care services. The program will run for five years starting 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The pilot program will run for five years starting 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary will select at least 250 eligible individuals to participate, giving priority to those who were part of a previous pilot program or agree to work as a physician assistant for the Veterans Health. Between January 2011 and February 2015, individuals can be employed as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration in medically underserved communities with a high percentage of veterans. The pilot program for educational assistance will run for five years, with priority given to previous participants or those willing to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health. The Secretary will provide educational assistance, including scholarships, for individuals in the pilot program to obtain a master's degree in physician assistant studies or a similar field. Existing programs like the Department of Veterans Affairs Health Professionals Educational Assistance Program will be utilized for this purpose. The Secretary will provide scholarships for individuals in the pilot program to obtain a master's degree in physician assistant studies. Participants must agree to work as a physician assistant for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of time. In the pilot program, individuals must fulfill a specified period of obligated service, which can vary based on the program they are participating in. Failure to comply with the obligated service may result in liability. An individual in the pilot program who fails to complete the obligated service will be liable to repay the amount received, except in certain circumstances. The liability for failing to complete obligated service in the pilot program will be determined as specified. Physician assistant mentors will be available for participants in the program at Veterans Health Administration facilities. The Secretary will partner with at least 15 accredited institutions offering master's degree programs in physician assistant studies. The pilot program requires accredited institutions to guarantee seats in master's degree programs for participants and provide admissions information. Other higher education institutions offering similar programs must also be accredited. The pilot program requires accredited institutions to guarantee seats in master's degree programs for participants and provide admissions information. The program is administered by the Secretary through various agencies and includes marketing to veterans and members of the Armed Forces. The Secretary appoints a Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants within the Office of Physician Assistant Services. The pilot program, administered by the Secretary, includes a Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants who oversees the program, recruits candidates, coordinates with participants, and assists in their admission to a master's degree program. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, a physician assistant and veteran, is responsible for coordinating the needs of the pilot program, providing mentors to participants, and managing facility staff. The pilot program participants are coordinated by the Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, who works with facility staff to identify employment positions and mentors. A recruiter reports to the Deputy Director and collaborates with various offices to develop national recruiting plans. The Office of the Veterans Health Administration is tasked with developing national recruiting strategic plans for physician assistants. An administrative assistant at a minimum GS-6 level assists with administrative duties in the Office of Physician Assistant Services. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in collaboration with other departments, must submit a report within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in collaboration with other departments, will submit a report to Congress on a pilot program for physician assistants. The report will assess the program's effectiveness in improving the skills of eligible individuals and meeting the shortage of physician assistants. The report will identify modifications needed for a pilot program to address the shortage of physician assistants and assess its potential as a model for other healthcare fields. The Department of Veterans Affairs will allocate at least $8,000,000 to support a pilot program aimed at helping individuals obtain certification and employment in various healthcare fields. Establishment of standards for the Department of Veterans Affairs to use educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish standards to improve the use of educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants within the Department. Directors of medical centers will be held accountable for not utilizing these programs to advance employees' education and enhance recruitment and retention of physician assistants. The Department of Veterans Affairs aims to enhance recruitment and retention of physician assistants by ensuring availability of the Education Debt Reduction Program for filling vacant positions. Compliance with educational assistance programs is monitored to support training and hiring of physician assistants. The Secretary will create programs to encourage Department employees to apply to physician assistant programs and will prescribe regulations to carry out this section. Establishment of pay grades for physician assistants of the Department of Veterans Affairs and requirement to provide competitive pay. The text discusses the establishment of pay grades for physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs, including competitive pay and a national strategic plan for their retention and recruitment. The Department of Veterans Affairs is establishing standards for competitive pay for physician assistants compared to the private sector. The Secretary must submit a report on the national strategic plan implementation to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within one year.
